enemy that great weapon, despair. So Archidamus says, that the enemy’s land is a hostage, to be spared that despair may not give them strength. So Agesilaus advised to let the Acarnians sow their land3 saying, that they would be all the more desirous of peace. So Juvenal, spoliatis arma supersum, when men have lost all they find arms. So Livy says the Gauls judged, when they took the city.

2 Add, that such a course, during war, presents the appearance of a great confidence of victory3 and that clemency is apt to bend and conciliate men's minds. So Annibal, in his conduct towards the Tarentines, does not waste the land ; not from moderation, but to con- ciliate them. So Augustus acted towards the Pannonians. So Timo- theus, in the case already mentioned, obtained the good will of the enemy.
